Dental Sealants

Dental sealants are a thin layer of plastic placed on the chewing surfaces of your molars at the back of your mouth to prevent cavities.

Cavity Prevention Made Easy

Dental sealants are a thin layer of plastic placed on the chewing surfaces of your molars at the back of your mouth – which are usually the teeth you use to chew your food. This simple preventive treatment provides powerful protection against cavities.

What Are Dental Sealants?

Dental sealants are protective, tooth-colored coatings applied to the chewing surfaces of back teeth (molars and premolars). They act as a barrier, protecting these cavity-prone areas from plaque and bacteria that cause tooth decay.

Why Molars Need Extra Protection

  • Deep grooves and pits trap food and bacteria
  • Difficult to clean with regular brushing
  • Experience heavy chewing forces
  • Most susceptible to decay in children and teens

Who Benefits Most from Sealants?

Children (Ages 6-14)

The ideal candidates as permanent molars emerge. Sealants applied soon after eruption provide maximum protection during cavity-prone years.

Best timing: First molars at age 6, second molars at age 12

Teenagers

High-risk period due to dietary habits and sometimes inconsistent oral hygiene. Sealants provide crucial protection during these vulnerable years.

Benefits: 80% reduction in cavities for up to 2 years, 50% for up to 4 years

Adults at Risk

Adults with deep grooves who haven't had cavities in their molars can still benefit. Also recommended for those with dry mouth or high cavity risk.

Candidates: Cavity-free molars with deep pits and fissures

The Sealant Application Process

1

Tooth Preparation

The tooth is thoroughly cleaned and dried. Any existing decay is removed if present. The chewing surface is prepared with a mild etching solution to help the sealant bond.

No anesthesia needed: The process is completely painless and non-invasive
2

Sealant Application

The liquid sealant material is carefully painted onto the chewing surface, flowing into all the grooves and pits. The material is then hardened using a special curing light.

Quick process: Each tooth takes only a few minutes to seal
3

Final Check & Polish

We check the bite to ensure the sealant doesn't interfere with chewing, make any necessary adjustments, and polish the surface. You can eat normally right after the appointment.

Immediate results: Protection starts working right away

Sealant Benefits & Effectiveness

Proven Protection

80%
Cavity Reduction

Sealants prevent 80% of cavities in back teeth for the first 2 years after application

50%
Long-term Protection

Continue to protect against 50% of cavities for up to 4 years

9x
Greater Protection

Children with sealants are 9 times less likely to develop cavities in sealed teeth

Additional Benefits

  • Cost-effective: Much less expensive than treating cavities
  • Painless: No drilling or tooth removal required
  • Quick application: Entire appointment typically under 30 minutes
  • Invisible protection: Clear or tooth-colored material
  • Long-lasting: Can last many years with proper care
  • Repairable: Can be touched up or reapplied if needed

Caring for Your Sealants

Do's

  • Brush and floss regularly as usual
  • Use fluoride toothpaste and mouthwash
  • Attend regular dental checkups
  • Eat a balanced diet low in sugary snacks
  • Have sealants checked and maintained regularly

Avoid

  • Chewing on ice or hard objects
  • Biting fingernails or pen caps
  • Using teeth as tools
  • Excessive grinding or clenching
  • Sticky candies that can pull off sealants

Sealants vs. Traditional Cavity Treatment

Aspect Sealants (Prevention) Fillings (Treatment)
Cost $30-60 per tooth $150-400+ per filling
Tooth Structure No tooth removal Drilling required
Comfort No anesthesia needed Local anesthetic required
Time 15-30 minutes total 45-60 minutes per tooth
Longevity 5-10 years average 5-15 years (varies by material)
Success Rate 80% cavity prevention 95% initial success rate

Prevent Cavities Before They Start

Dental sealants are one of the most effective preventive treatments available. Protect your family's teeth with this simple, painless procedure that can save time, money, and discomfort in the long run.

Frequently Asked Questions

How long do dental sealants last?

Dental sealants typically last 5-10 years, but can last even longer with proper care. They should be checked at regular dental visits and can be touched up or reapplied if they become worn or chipped.

Are sealants covered by insurance?

Many dental insurance plans cover sealants for children up to age 18, often at 100% coverage. Some plans also cover adult sealants. We'll help you understand your benefits and maximize your coverage.

Can adults get sealants?

Absolutely! Adults with cavity-free molars that have deep grooves can benefit from sealants. They're especially recommended for adults with high cavity risk, dry mouth, or those who want extra protection for their teeth.

Do sealants contain BPA?

Modern dental sealants contain trace amounts of BPA, but the exposure is extremely minimal - less than what you'd get from handling a receipt or eating canned food. The American Dental Association confirms that the benefits far outweigh any minimal risks.
